CSS - The difference between Margin, Border, and Padding

Sunday, May 11 2015

CSS Positioning is controlling the position of objects on webpages. This also defines how they look or dont look and also, how they behave with respect to each other.
CSS Positioning gives the flexibility to manipulate onjects to make the page more user friendly and presentable.

Here in the above Image, we can see a Box model. Each HTML element is like a tiny box which is marked above as Content; this holds the actual element for e.g pictures or text. The main properties which help in positioning are Margin, Border, and Padding

The Margin is the space around the element. The larger the size of the margin, the more space it will have with the elements around it. The margin does not have a background and is completely transparent. There are 4 different margins:

  • margin-top
  • margin-bottom
  • margin-right
  • margin-left
    •
To use these margins it is required to set them to a value. Hence following are the vlaues, you can set them to either of them:
  • auto - The browser calculates its values
  • length - Specifies a margin using some form like px, pt, cm, etc. Default value is 0 px.
  • % - Specifies margin in percentage of width of the containing element.
  • inherit - Specifies that the margin should be inherited from the parent element

You can set the value of the margins directly:
p {
margin-top: 100px;
margin-bottom: 100px;
margin-right: 150px;
margin-left: 50px;
}
or you can use a shorthand:
p {
margin: 100px 50px 50px 50px;
}

The Border is the edges of any html element. The border properties allows you to specify the style, size and color of any element.
Let's talk about Style. You can use the following syntex:
p {
border-style: your-style;
}
You can replace the 'your-style' in syntax with any of the following:

dotted
dashed
solid
double
groove
ridge
inset
outset

The width is set in pixels, or by using one of the three pre-defined values: thin, medium, or thick. For Width you have following syntax:
p {
border-width: 5px;
}

The border-color property is used to set the color of the border. The color can be set by: name - specify a color name, like "red" RGB - specify a RGB value, like "rgb(255,0,0)" Hex - specify a hex value, like "#ff0000" You can also set the border color to "transparent". For Width you have following syntax:
p {
border-color: red;
}

The Padding is the spacing between the content and the border. There are 4 different paddings:

  • padding-top
  • padding-bottom
  • padding-right
  • padding-left
    •
Like margins you can set the value of the padding directly:
p {
padding-top: 100px;
padding-bottom: 100px;
padding-right: 150px;
padding-left: 50px;
}
or you can use a shorthand:
p {
padding: 100px 50px 50px 50px;
}
